Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Student & Early Career Scientist Travel Support for the 2015 First Order Reversal Curve (FORC) Magnetism Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide travel support for a minimum of 25 U.S. graduate students and early career scientists to attend the 2015 First Order Reversal Curve (FORC) Workshop in Minneapolis at the University of Minnesota. First order reversal curves are elegant, nondestructive tools for characterizing the detailed magnetic behavior of carefully engineered materials as well as natural samples, and the goals of this two-day workshop are to (1) provide expert instruction on the fundamental physics that underlie this tool and (2) provide hands-on training for how to optimize the acquisition and processing of FORC data. This FORC Workshop is designed specifically for graduate students and early career researchers studying magnetism and related areas in the fields of engineering, physics, material sciences, and Earth sciences. It will consist of lectures by international experts who have helped push this technique forward and will
include poster presentations by participating graduate students. The program will cover the fundamental physics that underlie the FORC technique as well as recent developments and applications. We anticipate that the workshop will attract ~80 participants, and will be a unique opportunity for young scientists to meet leaders in their field in a relaxed and collegial atmosphere and to begin establishing a network of colleagues in the research community.

The FORC Workshop will provide training for graduate students and early career scientists to learn about a new and powerful magnetic characterization tool. Participants will learn how to optimize the collection of FORC data and gain the practical skills to process their
own data using advanced open-source software. In addition to formal lectures, each participating student will be required to present a poster about their current research. These topics will be discussed amongst the students and lecturers during poster sessions. All participants are encouraged to submit short papers to IEEE Magnetics Letters for peer-reviewed publication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnetism plays a pervasive role in our everyday life. It is difficult to imagine a world without the magnetic materials that run our computer hard drives, loudspeakers, ceiling fans, microwave ovens and many other items. Moreover, the advancement in important areas as information technology cannot continue without strong research activity in the field.  Further, the magnetic recording preserved in geological materials, such as rocks and sediments, acts as an archive of the Earth’s past magnetic field behavior (including geomagnetic reversals), and allows geoscientists to delineate the rate of plate tectonics, the age of sedimentary basins and ore deposits, as well as records of environmental climate change.

 Magnetism research is a multidisciplinary area in which engineers, physicists, chemists, materials scientists, and Earth scientists work together. As a result of this multidisciplinarity, professional training in the field of magnetism cannot be achieved under a traditional college degree taking courses under a single program. Typically, researchers working in these fields achieve their proficiency only after many years of independent and/or postgraduate studies.

‘First order reversal curves,’ or FORCs, are an important new magnetic characterization technique. These are elegant, nondestructive tools for characterizing the detailed magnetic behavior of carefully engineered materials as well as natural samples.  In order to provide better and more efficient training for this technique, PIs Feinberg and Spinu organized the 2015 FORC Workshop. During this two-day event, graduate students and early career scientists working in magnetism and related areas had the opportunity to learn from world experts about the fundamental theory and experimental details that underlie the FORC magnetic technique, as well as gain hands-on experience collecting and processing FORC data. Bringing together students from all geographical regions enabled collaborations of scientists working on magnetics research.

The workshop attracted 55 participants from around the world, and was a unique opportunity for young scientists to meet leaders in their field in a relaxed and collegial atmosphere and to begin establishing a network of colleagues in the broader magnetics research community. NSF funds provided opportunities for 27 U.S. graduate students and early career scientists (<5 years from completion of their Masters or PhD) to participate. Thirteen participants (24%) were women. Twenty-one participants (37%) were from the geosciences, twenty-eight participants (51%) were from the combined fields of materials science, physics, and engineering, and 7 participants (12%) were from industry.
